Let's start with the outside view. The first fact to note is that PM David Cameron has promised to hold a referendum on the UK's membership in the EU (a.k.a. Brexit[1]) before the end of 2017. (Both the Economist[2] and the BBC[3] have impeccable overviews.) How likely is it that Cameron will follow through on his promise? Pretty likely, I think. I'd be willing to make about a 100-to-1 bet in favor but not much lower, so let's say there's a 99% chance that there referendum will be held by the end of 2017. For the moment, I'm going to ignore this possibility, but I'll factor it back into the mix later. And I think it's safe to assume that the date for the vote would have to be announced no later than the end of September 2017. It's now (roughly) half of the way through February, so in order for Britain to set a date for the Brexit vote before the end of 2017, it has to do so in the remaining 19.5 months. Assuming that the date on which the Brexit vote is set is randomly determined, the probability of that Britain will set a date prior to May 1, 2016 is 1.0-(17/19.5) = 0.128. Why? I have done more research on secondary legislation mainly to satisfy my curiosity.  Unlike the US, the UK does not have a strict separation of powers doctrine and their executive and legislative branches are intertwined.  The delegation of authority from Parliament almost always goes to someone who answers to Parliament.  Although I have not found anything that says royal assent is not needed for SI’s, it makes sense based on how their system is set up.  The UK’s efforts in the last ten years to better separate the judiciary from the other branches is very interesting.

While I suspect the actual referendum will not be held until late 2016 or early 2017, I think the probability is relatively high that the current government will set the date of the referendum prior to 1 May.  While little apparent progress has been made on the negotiations for EU-UK treaty revisions and opt-outs, the upcoming election cycle in the UK (5 May 2016) and national elections in France and Germany in early-mid 2017 mean that the most probable window for a referendum would be mid- to late-2016, and an announcement prior to the UK local elections would likely benefit the current government (Conservative).  If no substantive progress is reported towards additional UK opt-outs or exemptions from EU treaties, or if conditions in the EU change dramatically (economically or otherwise), I could see the government making a case to postpone the referendum until late 2017 or even 2018, though that could lead to losses at the local election level for several years.

David Cameron first seeks to reform the UK's relationship with Brussels & Foreign Secretary Philip Hammond has said he wants to wrap up EU negotiations by the summer of 2016 if possible, and, if not, by the end of 2016. Late 2016/early 2017 is seen as the most likely time for the referendum to take place. No date has been set so far, with Mr Cameron saying the timescale should be determined by the renegotiation process (Sources: http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-33141819).

The Scottish referendum was flagged up 18 months in advance and it is likely that the Conservatives would like to get the referendum done whilst the opposition is still in a mess, hence suggesting a 2016 date rather than end-2017 and an early setting of the date.  If the incoming Dutch leadership of the EU is indeed sympathetic towards the UK's request for reforms, then the UK would be well advised to use this positive vibe before it wanes.  This again suggests a 2016 date.  If September is the preferred month (being after the long parliamentary recess), then an announcement to that effect by end-April would give a lead of less than 20 weeks.  However, referenda are very popular cans to kick down the street.  If talks with the EU don't work out exactly as hoped (which they rarely do) then adding another year to the lead time is a decent cop out.  With 3 summits in early 2016 and a 5 month gap between the June and October meetings, it is likely that any unresolved issues along the way will take the negotiations into June before a decision is considered, even re a September referendum.  Hence I would probably lean towards a decision in late June 2016 or beyond rather than 1/5/16.  In fact if Cameron wants a September referendum, is there any mileage in announcing it (or necessity to announce it) prior to the last summit before the recess?  I think probably not.
The date is usually announced at least a year out from the referendum, and it is reasonable to expect that Cameron will keep his word about having it before the end of 2017.
